reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s fat-tailed “value-efficiency” argument for why (on linear/unbounded views) mostly-great futures are a narrow target. That premise is a meaningful support for the ‘fussy’ conclusion, but it is not the only support (the position also leans heavily on moral-fragility/multiplicative-factor arguments and on bounded-view arguments), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The critique’s main move—technological maturity + copying/iterative optimization could produce a broad plateau of near-best designs, compressing tails—does weaken the fat-tail plausibility, but it’s largely speculative and doesn’t directly engage the essay’s specific supporting considerations (e.g., separability implying some maximally efficient configuration, the “uncertainty implies fat-tailed expectation” move, and the possibility that moral/value disagreement makes ‘good pattern’ copying hard). So strength is modest. Most statements are plausible and not clearly false (replicability and search/measurement can reduce dispersion), though claims like ‘may invert’ are under-argued and the critique doesn’t establish that tails would not remain heavy in relevant spaces. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little fluff.
title: The "fat-tailed value-efficiency" claim lacks empirical grounding
